reviewText: The movie is a cult classic. Was the day it was made. The costuming is over the top, International Male meets Fredrick's of Hollywood.  The two main characters work well together. Great humor and friendship. You feel their journey with them.The plot moves at a quick pace on an all but deserted Greek island. All the color comes from the onslaught of visitors to the latest hidden paradise.I will enjoy this piece for years to come.

reviewText: The plot for this 1967 film builds on an in-flight collision in 1966 in which four American nuclear bombs were briefly lost in coastal waters off Spain, causing so much hullabaloo that future flight crews faced with ditching their nuclear cargo were told to do so over isolated dry land whenever possible to facilitate secret recovery.So when an Air Force plane has to ditch its cargo of two nuclear bombs and a mysterious armor-plated box called "Q" just before the plane plunges largely unseen into isolated Mediterranean waters; the two flight crewmen (navigator Tom Courtenay and pilot Colin Blakely in a hilarious, bickering odd-couple relationship) dump their nuclear cargo via parachutes over a fortuitously near-by dry, sun-drenched, treeless, rocky Greek isle inhabited by only a small coastal fishing village and several inland goat farmers.  Though the crew are presumed killed in the crash by their superiors, they survive without injury and manage to swim ashore naked and starving, where they sneak about desperately seeking food and cover for their nakedness; hiding from occasional local residents, then from the ever-growing hordes of people, and finally from even their own side's unrecognizable 'under-cover' bomb recovery team!Meanwhile with unlimited budget, a top secret government team led by 'Elias' (Sam Wanamaker) is assembled to find and secretly secure and remove the two bombs and that mysterious box.  Wearing outrageous casual clothing to disguise their purpose, they arrive under-cover in a massive touring ship posing as a real estate speculator and investment firm sending a team in to scout out and thence build a Mediterranean tourist resort hotel complex on the isle.  Naturally the residents are delighted.  In record time, the "firm" "decides" that this dry, treeless, barren isle is the ideal spot for their resort and proceeds buying up large chunks of rock-strewn property; employing local residents to build a crude dirt access road to same; thus distracting locals while meanwhile searching frantically for the lost cargo with their "building equipment".When word inadvertently escapes to the outside world and international press of this "investment firm's" interest and that this isle presents massive growth and investment opportunities; and when ancient civilization artifacts like statues are unearthed during the road building process, everyone wants a piece of the action, descending on the isle and flooding it with ships and boats, speculators, archeologists, opportunity seekers, tourists and even merry-makers.TDTFCO takes a no-holds-barred approach to the black comedy possibilities; brilliantly and expertly exploiting every conceivable such niche.  The film lies somewhere between 1964's unremittingly grim Failsafe (a fine film totally devoid of comedy and which I can't bear watching because it's too realistic and depressing); and the caricatured, over-the-top black comedy of 1964's Dr. Strangelove.  I'll not recommend whether or not you should get this film.  I can only relate my experience:  A single TV viewing over forty years ago left me with indelible impressions of some truly unforgettable scenes!  (Such is also the case with Failsafe and Dr. Strangelove for different reasons.)  I searched for years to find a copy but was not successful - UNTIL NOW!  This DVD-R has just been released from Fox's film archive in August 2012!Typically DVD-R 'archive' releases are bare-bones, just the film with no extras, not even trailers, subtitles or CC.  I'd earlier ordered two such through Amazon from Warner's and Universal's 'archive collections.'  Their DVD-R re-mastered picture quality and sound were great and without any playing problems despite warnings that such might fail on certain non-read-only equipment (which may well be true in some cases).  Though the films' keep-case artwork was quite professional, the plastic part was pure junk and needed replacement (a pet peeve of mine).Though TDTFCO's film source seems in generally good shape, Fox has not re-mastered this 'archive' release so one sees and hears the occasional minor jump, some scratches and blemishes, a detraction but not sufficient to interfere with enjoyment of the film:  On my 32-inch 1080p Sony (1080x1920 pixels), the 4x3 picture has brilliant colors and is acceptably clear and detailed.  The mono sound is fine.  The disc has no chapter stops but one can step through the 109-minute film in ten-minute increments.  IMDB does not give the original aspect ratio.  The (normal quality) keep case blurb says full screen (4x3).  I believe such to be the original aspect as filmed, the picture being well-composed with no evidence of pan and scan tampering.As quite a bit of dialog is in Greek (with a smattering of other languages), English subtitles show automatically.  The film also relies on visual comedy, dialog being less important and even absent in some scenes.  I have hearing impairment and will usually refuse to buy a DVD without subtitles or CC.  But thinking so much of this film, I bought it anyway willing to accept the consequences as it will likely not be available in any other form in my lifetime.  To my surprise, the un-subtitled English dialog from the several principal well-schooled British actors was mostly comprehensible, being clear and well enunciated.TDTFCO's cinematography, casting, direction and pace (alternating attention between the various groups with frantic and building pressures) are first rate.  Despite the 4x3 aspect and the regrettable failure to film this incredible piece in widescreen; and despite Fox's failure to re-master and provide full subtitles, the product is otherwise fine.Warning:  If heart-warming feel-good anthropocentric films dominate your sensitivities and entertainment needs, you'd best stay away from this one.  Razor sharp teeth lurk just under the film's surface hilarity, having much in common with the two aforementioned films; highlighting mankind's hubris and folly, making fun of such, and then showing just where such logically leads.  When Mother Nature's axe falls, it isn't pretty.
summary: It's not nice to fool Mother Nature!
Title: N/A

reviewText: There's more than one message hidden under the outrageously hedonistic lifestyle depicted in this movie, ....and quite a bit of biting satire for those astute enough to see past what first appears to be a fairly "light" comedy.Two pilots jettison a couple of atom bombs and a very mysterious but heavily armoured box over a Greek island backwater called Caros.After their plane crashes into the ocean, they swim ashore. It's never explained how they manage to lose not only their orange flight suits but boots and socks as well.They spend the rest of the movie running around in just their white briefs, .....one bloke in the tiniest pair of white Y-fronts you can imagine, that don't manage to hide anything at all really, specially when wet! Brave boy!While they get minimalist wardrobe, just about everybody else except the locals gets the full on "International Male" or "Fredericks of Hollywood" treatment, ..with some of the "gayest" little beach ensembles you are ever likely to see, ....all fetchingly accessorised to the max! The hat/sunglasses/visor all-in-one combos are something really special!The plot revolves around the search for the aforementioned mysterious box, ...which has already been found and stashed away by a local goat-herder and his wife. They spend fruitless hours trying to work out how to open the box, hoping for gold or other treasure. (At this stage we don't know exactly what the contents may be, but we guess they must constitute great danger from nuclear radiation.)Meanwhile the team of other "military personnel" dressed in their natty little outfits search diligently without success. This sets off a tourist boom.The glitterati jet set, bored with their usual watering holes, assume that Caros (the island) just has to be the very latest  place to be seen.They swamp the island and of course the locals are delighted with the financial possibilities.Suddenly Caros is "IN", and everybody just has to be there!Every now and then the beautiful people break into this wild synchronised dance routine called "The Jet". It's performed to some Zorba-On-Acid type music played on bouzouki...naturally!(You can hear samples here on Amazon under the soundtrack which is still available.)One of the over-dressed-under-dressed crowd is a female supposed art historian, played by a VERY early Candice Bergen before she was anything but a model.She's minimally clad of course, and sexually on the prowl.She proceeds to have probably THE most unlikely sex scene you will ever witness on any movie.She's OK if a little wooden, ....but her supposedly eager partner is without doubt the most obvious (and visibly uncomfortable!) gay bloke you are ever likely to see trying to play the hetero-macho stud! (I was about to say he was "wooden" too, but I'm betting there was none of that commodity evident at all on his person!)Of course he's not helped by the far-from butch wardrobe department, but the poor guy is just SO off the scale "gay" and hollow chested that this scene alone will break you up. Thankfully the unlikely couple disappear UNDER(?) the bed before we have to witness either of their obviously impending disappointments.You just know neither of them are going to find what they want....ahem!Candice Bergen later starts doing some sort of artistic reproduction work in heavy sheet metal, for which she employs a substance that we are told will eat through absolutely everything.(Now how they keep it in a glass bottle and deliver it through a plastic tube and glass nozzle is not explained either!)She handles the highly dangerous stuff bare handed, splashing it about with no protective gear at all, dressed in just more minimalist attire, but all the while looking gorgeous of course.Naturally the goat-herder sees this stuff in action and purloins the substance to open the box he has secreted in his hovel.(It apparently doesn't damage his arms or that of his wife either!)Meanwhile back at the beachfront,  The Ship of Fools dances to the end.There's some very clunky dialogue at times that suggests to me that the actors were just given the gist of the scene and then allowed to improvise.The cinematography is bright and cheerful, and it's obvious that so many of the local inhabitants were used as extras.You will be dazzled by the outfits! At times this reminded me of "Barbarella" in its portrayal of the bizarre trend-setting fashion-victims.Of course the movie "ends" the only way it can.There IS just no answer to what ensues and although no real ending is even shown, we all know only too well what it means when "The Fish Come Out".
Title: N/A

reviewText: I never caught "The Day the Fish Came Out" on television and the critical panning it received upon release in 1967 as some catastrophic waste indulging a gifted young director prevented me from trying harder to see it but still a tad intrigued.  The director (who had had an AAN for "Zorba the Greek"), Michael Cacoyannis could recoup his critical damage by this new release by the new 20th Century-Fox Cinema Archives, the 20th version of Warner Archive in MOD DVD-R editions.  They did not restore "The Day the Fish Came Out" and it does look raw, almost amateurish with no extras and a few blemishes and scratches.  Cacoyannis wrote, produced and directed, and even did the costumes which are supposedly futuristic set ahead in 1972 (remember "Camille 2000's" costumes?").  These have the influence of the films of Fellini from the sixties and today seem to find an acceptance on the screen as neither too "effete" or too "awful."  The setting in the future of the story in 1972 A.D. gives us an amazing look at our future from a past perspective.  It makes the film's success now beyond pertinent, but a brilliant vision of humanity, especially now in all the wild, bizarre and sexual and obsessive society.  amazon is now selling this film's soundtrack in a CD-R edition and the music by Mikis Theodorakis compliments the film nicely.  I believe he also did the choreography which does for the film the exact opposite the new release of the musical re-make of "Lost Horizon" which reveals embarrassingly bad choreography by Hermes Pan.  Here, it lifts your spirits.  Tom Courtenay, rarely the star, but always one to deliver finely etched performances, and Colin Blakely are both brilliant as the two pilots, playing the hilarity as well as Cacoyannis's razor-sharp view of human nature.  I too still have not seen "Zorba the Greek" his previous 1964 success, but I had a better time with TDTFCO than I've ever had with "Fellini Satyricon" or "8-1/2."  Sam Wannamaker makes a viral leader and Candice Bergen is a vision of stunning beauty and the right comedic touch to add to it.  The Color by Deluxe is a bit washed out, I think Cacoyannis should have prepared for that better as the film itself did not age well but what is in it was miles ahead of its time, right now.
summary: Flop Film Takes You By Storm

reviewText: Released in 1967, "The Day the Fish Came Out" was the next film of director/writer Mihalis Kakogiannis after his acclaimed "Zorba the Greek" (1964). This a cold war satire that includes elements of "The Russians Are Coming, the Russians Are Coming," "Dr. Strangelove, Or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb (Special Edition)," "Village of the Giants" and the goofier James Bond flicks of the 60s-70s, e.g. "Thunderball (Special Edition)" and "Diamonds Are Forever."THE PLOT: After NATO plane goes down near a desolate Greek island, the two British pilots wander around in their underwear trying to find the dangerous nuclear cargo they unloaded. Also looking for the weapons is an Air Force team that comes to the island masquerading as hotel entrepreneurs. The pilots mistake them as a group of gay guys due to their gaudy apparel and lack of female companionship. Once word gets out that the island may be the next hotspot, vacationers start flocking to the island in droves. The tourists include a man-crazy blond (Candice Bergen) who sets her eyes on a member of the Air Force team. Meanwhile, a peasant couple find the most dangerous weapon and threaten to contaminate the environment when they insist on opening it.I saw this film a couple times on TV as a kid (at least the last hour or so) and it left a lasting impression. Seeing it again recently, it holds up pretty well. The build-up is a bit too long because the story doesn't get compelling until the final 40 minutes, but the final act is worth the wait. Besides, the film is still fairly entertaining even during the slow build-up. I had quite a few laughs.Some people have complained about the dancing and clothing of the vacationers (and the Air Force Team), but the film was apparently depicting events in the near future. I'm sure 1972 seemed very futuristic in 1966 when the film was written. The strange dancing and apparel must be viewed with this in mind. Besides, these elements and the wild music are part of the film's charm, the same way the dancing, apparel and music of "Village of the Giants" make it so worthwhile (despite its badness).If you have a taste for wacky late 60 or early 70s cinema, "The Day the Fish Came Out" is a must. There's really nothing else quite like it. And those final 40 minutes are great. Too bad it takes an hour and 10 minutes to get there.The film was shot on location in Greece.GRADE: B+
Title: N/A
